reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Informative and touching
reviews.reviewText: A very interesting, heartfelt story of a hospial for those with leprosy in 1920’s Louisiana. Really appreciated the author’s research and compassion. The story is a bit long winded but overall, worthwhile. Have kleenex handy.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars interesting but sliw
reviews.reviewText: This books provided a glimpse into an interesting point of history of which I was unfamiliar. The book was well enough written but was not truly captivating. I didn't much care for many of the characters. However, the book was interesting enough to make it through.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Unusual topic with great story and history Will keep your interest and the details are on point . Makes a book so enjoyable.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2024
reviews.reviewText: It was hard to read about theIllness and what it does to theBody. We don't realize what people go through sometimes to teach a cure for diseases.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A glimpse into how society stigmatizes some illnesses
reviews.reviewText: This is the second novel I have read that focuses on leprosy. An illness that for years made those afflicted by the illness pariahs even after they were cured. Much of the fear was based on erroneous assumptions about how it was transmitted and the low frequency of its actual transmission from one person to another.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great mix of historical fiction & medical fiction.
reviews.reviewText: Would absolutely recommend this to anyone who likes historical and medical fiction, or nonfiction, as the author did a great job of researching to make it fit how life would have actually been like had Mirielle been real.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Mirielle is diagnosed with Leprosy. She was under the impression her stay at the Carville was to be a couple months. Those months turned to years. She had to leave behind a husband and two daughters. Her time at Carville has been challenging due to her thinking she has been misdiagnosed. In order to leave the facility she needs to test negative 12 times straight.It was a good read I also did the audible which I feel like the narrator did a terrible job. All her “characters” sounded exactly the same in a manly voice. If they had gone with someone else that can actually do different voices it would’ve been better. 3 stars mainly due to the narrator sucking.Book 4 starsNarrator 2 stars

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Wow. What an incredible book. I finished it and immediately wanted to discuss it with anyone who had read it. It truly haunted me. Best book I have read this year. Have recommended it to many!!

I didn’t want to read a book about leprocy. I almost put the book down, but was so glad I kept going. The author’s writing style is totally addictive. She took a horrible situation and made it into a beautiful story. Will be reading more of her work very soon!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 23, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: A good read and a learning curve
reviews.reviewText: I liked the pace of the book, mostly was the transition from wealth and acceptance to being an outsider in a different world. Her character was so sad and spoiled but the humane kindness was always there.
A bit brutal if you did not already have some historical knowledge of this subject, but overall, it kept my interest to the end and was an enjoyable read, if sad in places.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 11, 2023
reviews.reviewText: It is interesting to get an insight into life for someone with this disease in the 1920's. The story follows Mirielle as she is diagnosed and sent to a specialist hospital. Although her story is sad, the emotion didn't come through in the writing. Unfortunately it is sometimes hard to sympathise with her as she is a self-centred character. However, I enjoyed reading the book and meeting the other characters.

A glorious read, well written and entirely unforgettable.Mirielle’s story will stay with you long after you finish this book. The 20’s comes to life in her most unusual story and the triumph of the human spirit is woven throughout this novelRead it, you won’t regret the time spent.
